summary: We opt for a data-driven approach by developing a new corpus with fine-grained entity annotation, covering three centuries of literature corresponding to the early modern period, We then fine-tune existing state-of-the-art architectures obtaining results that are on par with those of the current state-of-the-art NER systems for Contemporary English.
title: A Data-driven Approach to Named Entity Recognition for Early Modern French

summary: We determine that the importance of the pre-training dataset size was largely overestimated, as we are able to repeatedly show that language models can be pre-trained with corpora of a modest size.

summary: We present the $\\text{FreEM}\_{\\text{max}}$ corpus of Early Modern French and D'AlemBERT, a RoBERTa-based language model trained on $\\text{FreEM}\_{\\text{max}}$.

summary: we take the existing multilingual web corpus OSCAR and its pipeline Ungoliant that extracts and classifies data from Common Crawl at the line level, and propose a set of improvements and automatic annotations in order to produce a new document-oriented version of OSCAR.
